subject: Re: Is it Time for JUnit 5
msgSnippet: The Java 8 will be compatible with JavaFX on bytecode level. The same with lambda language, and other languages mentioned by the Oracle. It looks like NOT all
messageBody:
The Java 8 will be compatible with JavaFX on bytecode level.
The same with lambda language, and other languages mentioned by the Oracle.

It looks like NOT all lambda syntax works in the current JDK 1.8, but what I tried that works is the annonymous functions
() -> { System.out.println("..."); }

These are compiled to private package classes implementing java.util.functions.Block.

In my guess, the framework may be able to receive these functions like: JUnitCore#run(Block... blocks)

calling it like

JUnitCore.run(
() -> { assertThat(...); },
() -> { assertThat(...); }
)

I do not know how it would be with annotations on these functions, and encapsulations.

BR, Tibor


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "jens_schauder" wrote:
>
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Kevin Cooney wrote:
> [..]
> > I was thinking about that. JavaScript is a functional language, but all of
> > the JS test frameworks that I am aware of use JUnit-like syntax for
> > defining test cases (JsUnit defines test functions at global scope,
> > JsTestDriver uses methods on a class). If functional programming could
> > change the paradigm for defining tests, you would think it would have
> > happened in JavaScript.
> >
> > Am I missing something?
>
> Whenever I checked with my limited understanding of JavaScript and its ecosystem I was extremely week on the unit testing side of things.
>
> Also the JS syntax doesn't lend itself to usage of closures as part of a DSL.
>
> To be more specific. With ScalaTest FunSuites a test looks like this
>
> test("a test testing something"){
> // the actual test code
> }
>
> With Java8 I think it might look similar to this:
>
> test("a test testing something"){ =>
> // the actual test code
> };
>
> In JavaScript it would look more or less like:
>
> test("a test testing something", function(){
> // the actual test code
> });
>
> In current Java:
>
> test("a test testing something", new Runnable{
> public void run(){
> // the actual test code
> }
> });
>
> I think one can identify some difference in verbosity, which might be part of the reason why this style didn't become popular with JS.
>
> regards
> Jens
>
